body.p: New York, February 10th 1860
Sir:

I send you this folder to make you
? argumented at once with the intention
which I have in writing this letter. Now
that my Academy has been opened I want
to get acquaint make myself known to the
readers of your paper. The least ? to do that
would be to insert a note in your paper, telling
of the opening of my Academy. I also want
you to let me know as soon as possible
how much you would take for a one year
advertisement. I am sure, without
professing vanity that you have heard of my
name and took notice. I call your
attention to the style of the advertisement
as I would like to see it in your paper.
Very truly yours
New York Febr. 10Th 1860.
Mein Herr!

SELECT MALE AND FEMALE ACADEMY,
OR
CLASSICAL ENGLISH AND COMMERCIAL INSTITUTE,
>A DAY AND BOARDING SCHOOL,

p.placeName: No. 88 West 25th Street, near Seventh Avenue, N.Y.

body.p:
Although this is a new Institution, it should be understood, that the Principal who was formerly leader of one of the
best Schools in the city, in which his services have been considered so valuable as to be retained for a series of years, has been
thus accredited for his system of Instruction as to have received numerous testimonials of the most complimentary character
from gentlemen of the highest standing in the community, inviting him to open a DAY AND BOARDING SCHOOL of the first
order.

The aim and scope of this Institute is the cultivation and development of the youthful mind, in all that pertains to the
embellishment of thought and language, and the implanting of high oral principles as a guide to conduct and action: nor
shall it yield to any in its character for thoroughness and efficiency in imparting instruction, as well as securing good discipline,
by encouraging the acquisition of knowledge, without the application of coersive measures.
FURTHER PARTICULARS

The number of pupils is limited, so as to procure the greatest perfection in instruction and general deportment, thus
enabling the professors to comprehend fully the capacity and requirements of each Pupil.

The Class-rooms are admirably constructed to secure health and comfort, being spacious, well-lighted, well-ventilated and
provided with desks and seats suited to the height of the youth.

It is hoped that every Pupil will be as constant and punctual in his attendance as possible, else the Principal would not
be responsible for the advancement of such as are placed under his care.

With a view to a more rapid progress, as well as to inculcate habits of self-reliance, Day Pupils are required to study one
or two hours daily, at home, under the supervision of their parents.

A daily record is made of each pupil's attendance, deportment and scholarship, and the results are embodied in a monthly
report to the Patrons of the School. The attention of the parents is particularly requested to these reports, which will be sent
them regularly.

Tuition will be charged from the date of entrance, invariably in advance, and no deduction will be made for absence unless
in case of protracted sickness, when the loss will be divided equally between the Principal and the Parents.

It is expected that every Boarding Pupil will be furnished with bed and bedding, including linen in full, as also with table
napkins and a complete set of articles for the toilet.

The Course of Instruction affords facilities for the acquirement of complete Mercantile accomplishments and for the pur-
suit of those higher studies necessary for a polite education.
It embraces as follows:
CHARGES.
For Board, Washing, Lodging, Fuel, Light and Tuition, per Year, —— $300.00
For Day Pupils as follows:
For the First Class, per Quarter, ————— $20.50
No extra charges, except for Music, Stationery and Fuel.
REMARKS.

The Principal assures his patrons that special attention will be given to the moral and religious culture as well as the
manners and habits of the youth entrusted to his care, particularly of those who become members of his family.

Every facility will be afforded to the pupils in acquiring a thorough acquaintance with, and a correct and finished pronun-
ciation of, the English French, and German Languages: all of which will be spoken both in the School and Family.
REFERENCES.

With respect to References, DR. RIDSKOFF need only say, that all those distinguished names given, generally, by the
Jewish Private Schools of this city, are given also by him.
Select Male and Female Academy
or Classical English and Comercial Institute
A Day and Boarding School
